author: cian riordan
content:
Outside of the studio? This totally changed me. Seeing things through… start to finish. Caring about every step of the process. We’ve done so many home DIY projects… I’d be up late the night before planning, up early double checking. Staying afterward to make sure everything to put away and cleaned up. I care. Invaluable in building a home studio. I enjoy the results every day, even 5 years later I get a grin when I walk into that room.

Learning to cook pizza? Figure out where you want be. I started doing this 2 years ago. I had no idea what I was doing. But I limited my variables, took things one step at a time. What kind of flour is best? Buy different ones. Try them. What hydration dough? Fuck if I know. Start with 60%… work up from there. How long to ferment? Etc Etc. I obsess over every step of this process. 

When I’m interested in something, I care about it. Nobody else has to, but I do. And I’ll go to bed at night, I’ll know that I’ve done the work to really know that it’s as good as it can be.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It sounds like you're using their browser site to navigate your files, correct? I hate to say it but that's clunky as hell and you may as well be using Google Drive at that point (No!). Using Dropbox in-browser to navigate should be a last resort.

The move here is to connect Dropbox with your desktop so that your Dropbox folder appears and functions like any other folder in your Finder window. It will be far far easier to manage your files this way because they now have all of the same navigation functionality as your local files. 

I understand your desire not to download everything from your DB to your local drive. That's an easy thing to control once you wrap your head around how selective sync works. Once you get DB set up on your desktop you can specify that nothing should be downloaded to your local drive unless you specify (online-only), but you will still be able to see all of the cloud files inside of your DB folder in the Finder.

If you decide you want to download a file to your local drive you can right-click on the file and tell it to download (make available offline). And if later you decide to remove it from your local drive and make it cloud-only you can select "make online only". It's pretty simple once you get up to speed on the workflow.

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: My 2c: from August 2024 to October 2025 I worked with an artist where they brought me bones of songs and we co-wrote an albums worth of work together. They moved from the city to central massachusetts and while the songs and mixes are about 80% done, they can't get above water time and travel wise to finish the project and its put on hold for next year. This is a big record for me as a producer and musician, and it sucks that I put so much time and effort into it but in the end, I hope waiting it out  and getting back to refocus in 2026 will be worth it. On the other hand, I get hired by a band, they are super intense and ambitious about recording, mixing, and releasing - the album comes out and they breakup in 3 months or theres a lineup change where the new drummer has a home studio and can record everything there and mix it then 6 months later I get a IG dm to bail them out becuase the drummer fucked the guitarists wife and the bass player and vocalist are just going to finish the record on their own with me.

author: cian riordan
content: On this note, I'll say that I LOVE these drives. My workflow in the past has basically been to buy a new 1GB SSD drive every few projects. When I had my setup on a laptop, this allowed me to always have access to projects I was working on the go (printing stems on the couch while watching TV? Yes please). In addition to using these SSDs, I'd always keep local backups with 'Sync Folders Pro' -- RIP Sync X -- on a cheaper, larger capacity USB drive. Being an anxious data archiver, I also signed up for Backblaze a few years ago as a cloud solution in case my studio burns down. Its a really great service, but the caveat they have with your drives is you *can* back up externals, they just need to be connected to your computer every 30 days. So I bought this monster USB3 hub and just had all of these fucking SSDs connected to my computer whenever it was setup at my studio. It worked fine for a few years, but I ran out of space again a few weeks ago and decided to futureproof mysetup a little bit. I ended up getting a thunderbolt Drobo. That way, I could have redundant storage for archived projects (which also gets uploaded to backblaze) but without having 16 drives on my desktop. Now I just have two of those samsung SSDs -- one work, and one as a backup. They run lightning fast and I get to keep having local backups in case I fuck the dog moving files around after a few glasses of wine. Then, when I run out of space, I just offload onto the Drobo and it's locally redundant, and also backed up on the cloud. Thank you for coming to my TED talk.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I have a scalding hot take that the “indie girl” voice isn’t a fad and came about because it’s the optimal way to sing for the medium. 

Think of how opera doesn’t sound like human speech. That alien sound came about because extremely loose muscles create far less sympathetic intermodulation which sounds cleaner. It’s the same as how a speaker makes your desk vibrate and create out of time interference pattern distortions. Muscle tension creates hard surfaces that do the same when singing and opera singers obsess over undoing this. This is a big reason why so many of your favorite vocalists are opioid and benzo addicts. It’s not just culture. Downers are performance enhancing here. (Please don’t get any ideas artists) 

The modern pop voice is just maintaining that exaggerated opera looseness but with adaptations for the modern medium: English diphthongs instead of Latin ones, way less air in their lungs because the target is a foot from their mouth instead of 50 feet, and softened fricatives because a capsule right in front of the mouth harshly exaggerates fricatives. 

From a physics perspective it’s the perfectly optimized way to sing in 2024. You may not like it, but this is what peak performance sounds like

author: Rollmottle
content:
Some people will never realize their agency. That doesn’t mean they don’t have it. We all have it. The degree to which we build upon and leverage what we do have is our puzzle to solve.

I’ve had countless conversations with lost folks who think success and the things they say they want just happen. It is VERY difficult to teach self determination to people who don’t inherently believe that taking direct action toward a goal makes things start to happen. A lot of people don't believe it can be that simple. This doesn't mean it's easy. It can be hard to overcome one’s wiring and circumstances. And sometimes people need to learn the hard way. But, outside of the extreme, everybody’s got the agency to make their desired outcomes happen. Some need to work at it harder than others. For some, it comes easier. And sadly some never realize that their outcomes are in their hands. But what a powerful realization it should be that the things we think we can’t do are often just ourselves telling us we can’t do them, when in fact we absolutely can.

author: Slow Hand
content: Of all the studios I've worked in, my favorites are the ones that skew towards the home-y vibe. Lots of different couches and chairs to relax on. Variable lighting. Numerous stations and tables where everyone can go off, spread out, and work on their own stuff on the side. I know that's a luxury that requires a certain amount of space, but if the control room isn't set up like an arrow in which all stations are pointing forward towards the desk/speakers I find that's a big mental relief.

author: BatMeckley
content: Back in my day I had to climb up the hill carting my desktop computer with crt screen to use dial up internet. In the snow. Barefoot, cause we used our shoes for toys. Had to whistle a perfect 2600hz tone just to connect.

author: LAPhill
content:
I've only worked at Abbey Road once. I was there for a week and it was palpable from the front-desk to the interns, assistants, musicians, engineer, everyone silently acknowledged their fortune to be working in such hallowed ground. It just made it really clear that every single person cared, and cared deeply. I'm sure not all studios in London are quite like that, but it's stuck with me.

I've worked at all the scoring stages in town and many of the record studios and it's just different here. The closest I've come to experiencing that level of care and respect for the work being done was at Capital. This isn't a judgement about talent, but the demeanor. If an intern or assistant acts like they don't care or aren't as invested as everyone else in the room, it can bring down a session. Or at the very least, it starts to feel like they're in the way, not on your side. If an artist or engineer has mostly had that kind of experience, I can see defaulting to seeing the assistants as "the help" instead of an integral part of the team, deservedly so or not.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I’m convinced that electrostats are the way if sonics are priority 1 and money is no object. When I first heard a pair it changed my understanding of what’s possible. It seemed like an order of magnitude drop in distortion from the next cleanest alternative. Like the monitoring equivalent of going from a 57 to a josephson, and flagship planars are the 57. 

I thought it would be an instapurchase and then I found out the amp I was listening on cost $20k and I didn’t have enough info to know how to recreate that experience for less so I just set it aside. 
Most electrostatic amps measure so poorly and so I’ve stopped looking, but I’m hoping one day a DCA Corina and an affordable comparable amp will show up on my desk inexplicably

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll take a swing. It's 1/4 of the price of an OP-1, it's half the size of a Push, it's tightly integrated with Live, it's a standalone tool (if you desire), it's battery powered, and it's portable.

The biggest features for me are that it can fit on a desk without taking up massive real-estate and gives me the ability to play in drums, keys, *and* have 8 mappable encoders that are tightly synced with *Live*. For me it would replace drum pads, encoders, a tiny keyboard, and a *Launchpad* that would otherwise go on my desk. It's pretty damn elegant in that regard.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Just got this same spec also last weekend.  About a week in, it's definitely a little crowded for finishing work in my opinion but I'm use to working on a 1440p 24" monitor.  I can always HDMI I figure if I need the extra real estate.

The only acustica plug I run regularly is Ruby 2 - seems to cause pretty drastic spikes on the CPU short term in Ableton (running rosetta mode and VST3 by the way) but then it levels out.  In general I've been super impressed with the performance vs my desktop.  I'd say for my mixes it runs maybe 80% as well on large projects (75+ tracks, lots of processing) which was more than I was expecting.  Smaller projects and productions and softsynths it absolutely chews through compared to my desktop.

Was just trying out a little mix in Studio One just on the 14" and it felt very cramped to me.  I think it'd be hard to completely mix at this resolution but again it probably has more to do with what I'm used to.  Would definitely recommend a separate display if you are going to be doing all your work on it.

author: Will Melones
content: My thinking exactly. My rig was pretty solid when I left it alone, but every once in a while I would have a part crap out and a lot of downtime troubleshooting. It finally got to a point in the middle of a project that it was rejecting random plugins and having trouble booting, and I needed stability. So I started drawing out a map of dongles and hubs that I’d need if I were to replace it, and now I’m up and running on a MacBook Pro that’s more powerful than my 4GHz desktop was.

author: sukhuno
content: To mirror what Bradley said - the ability to use 1 cable for everything at my studio is invaluable. Especially if I have mobile sessions, I don’t have to worry about grabbing power cables or adaptors, etc. I just grab my laptop and drives and I’m good to go. And then when I wanna work at home , I plug in the one cable and I got everything (synths, interface, screen, drives, keyboard mouse). Also underrated benefit of the dock is how much cleaner cable management was under my desk when all the cables go to one place.

author: mixedbywong_my
content:
Was working on the computer , when one of the plugins I wanted to remove from an insert crashed Cubase. After that , I force restart on the MacBook pro via the power button . When  the computer restarted ,  the desktop folders are missing and it’s still in the directory somewhere in the system drive but it was renamed to Desktop - MacBook Pro (originally it’d be only Desktop)

Then the Finder kept freezing intermittently 🌈 ,  check activity monitor , shows “mds” & “mds_stores” taking up a lot of cpu for no reason (40-50%)
I’ve restarted the MacBook twice and it seems to be the same.  
My only possible solution would be restoring a time machine backup . Do I need to deauthorise my ilok licenses before i restore the backup . 
Has anyone possibly encountered something like this before ? Really sucks when there’s few mixes happening at the same time  and this happens. 😢😢😢

author: Eric Martin
content:
I’m coming to an impasse; I’m in a band that works a lot and I record our stuff, and I get a lot of work Mastering and Mixing. The more I do that the more I realize that the production and tracking are significantly more important than MIX/MSTR for the “success of the song”.

I’d love to put my hands on outboard mastering gear but I have a few upgrades that I would like to do for my tracking situation(full live band tracking) and the costs are about the same for either, I get a little less work tracking but it’s like 40% Mastering 35% Tracking and 25% Mixing work.

Most mixes I do all in the box and the little outboard I have helps shape the tracking upfront and doesn’t get used in Mastering, but does get used sometimes in mixing.

I operate out of my home studio which provides low overhead, my “studio” is where my band rehearses and where I Mix and Master, I also bring bands in occasionally to track in my basement, but it a little tight.

I wonder what y’all’s thoughts are, I love doing all these things but feel like, I’m just kinda stuck treading water and not swimming toward a destination.

author: Will Melones
content:
With the trackball I always feel the tendency to keep my hand in handshake position and roll it with my pinky anyway.

But maybe the biggest benefit to never leaving the house for the past two+ years has been not working at other people’s gigantic desks. My tabletop is *really* low, like elbows in my lap low. Someone taller than me wouldn’t be able to sit under it, but it’s very comfortable and relieves all the pinching and weird elbow/wrist contortions of a high work surface.

author: peterlabberton
content: How do folks handle clients you don’t know asking to come over in person for, say, mix revisions? I honestly didn’t think much of this when I moved from a shared studio space to a home studio. The vast majority of my work has been through friends, and it’s only recently I’ve been regularly working with randos who hit me up for work. Have had a couple recently who wanted to do in person work, and while I’m sure it’s fine and I wouldn’t think twice if it was a commercial space, it just slightly wigs me out that it’s my house. I dunno, maybe I’m overthinking this, just curious people’s experiences and thoughts!

author: CK
content: Question.....as far as productivity and work-life balance....Home Studio or Studio space that is not at your home?  Other than the financial part (let's assume you can easily afford the "not home" space), would you prefer a space at home or a dope space you can go to every day?  I am currently confronted with this choice and am unsure which I want to commit to. I know there is nuance to everyones situation. I am just brainstorming and making pros and cons lists at the moment.  I have always had a home space, so this would be a different daily routine for me. I imagine most folks here work from home.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone here host their personal music collection in the cloud? I've got a massive collection that could get more love, so I figure I should look into a solution for engaging with it more often.

What I'm seeking is:
1) My entire 500gb collection hosted in the cloud
2) The ability to organize and catalog everything meticulously.
3) A desktop and phone app that will allow me to stream any of it at will. Like using Spotify on your phone.
4) Requires very little in the way of ongoing subscription costs.
5) (Edit) Ideally it would be open-sourced or robust enough that if the developer closes the tools will still function.

Does anyone know of any options that satisfy most of those needs?

author: spectrummasters
content: ....I’m currently going into  another electrical engineering rabbit hole that’s got me learning the details of the routing of the old SSL 4000 desks (just by online docs and discussion ) and I have to say when it comes to signal flow , those SSL engineers were bloody clever .....With the whole in line thing and matrix and float etc etc .....it makes me realise how much of our daw s mixers and the routing options we have available ......we owe the concepts to the brain waves of electrical engineers in the 70s , they really thought shit through !!! TIP O my hat to the-electrical  engineers

author: peterlabberton
content:
Having just bought my first place with my girlfriend, AND having listened to that Daily episode, I definitely think it can be awesome but isn’t *always* awesome. We were very close to backing out of the process, until we saw the place we got, and the determining factor for us was that it had an ADU, and was in our budget. There’s work (and money to sink into said work!) we need to do, but once we have a tenant in, even conservatively I think it will either cover our mortgage, or come close to it. (It’s very likely NOT going to cover tax and insurance, but that’s more than fine.) We also were in a really fantastic first time homeowners program, which allowed us to put only 2% down, and gave us a grant for another percentage point down. This is all helped IMMENSELY by my girlfriend both having a real deal grownup salaried job and having just about perfect credit. But it’s going to allow us to build wealth through the house, and allow me to build my studio space, AND if we ever want to leave LA, because our interest rate is comparatively great, we’d just keep it and rent both units.

So, TLDR, I don’t think it’s a slam dunk always great idea, but I think if you can finagle the situation to work for you, it can be really smart.

Also, my entire family on my mom’s side has been school teachers/librarians/pastors/professors (so doing fine but by no means rich), but my parents and their parents were both able to ride California real estate into a very comfortable place in retirement.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Best thing I've ever done to fix dirty power was find a good electrician....   not just a dude with a truck, but someone willing to work with the problem.  We replaced/added a better earth rod to the box, and found a bad breaker.  Solved the worst of my dirty problems.  Having a 3000 dollar power conditioner at that point also helped some....   but that's like room correction.  Don't count on it. Fix the space first.

author: Slow Hand
content:
What's the strategy with aliases and forwarding?

On the whole I'm very happy with Gmail. In fact, the phone app works great. I'm very happy with it. However, I have so many accounts that it's cumbersome in a browser to open a window to check for updates on each account. I wish there was a consolidated viewer, or some sort of global indicator to show me my total number of new messages across all accounts.

Ideally, Google would just make their own desktop app. Unfortunately desktop software is against their strategy these days. So we're unlikely to see that.

author: Slow Hand
content: I guess at the end of the day I'm looking for a more centralized experience while using Gmail on the desktop. The phone experience is great.

author: andrew_yv
content: Spark is pretty good as both a desktop and iPhone email manager, though I did have occasional issues with it. But the main draw for me was that it would auto categorize emails into categories like promotional and newsletters, including non Gmail accounts. I’ve recently switched to Canary which is better in some ways and worse in others. I’d say both are worth looking into
